name: Insufficient Solder
description: Solder joint does not have adequate solder coverage, resulting in weak electrical connection or potential open circuit.
failureAnalysis: Visual inspection revealed inadequate solder wetting on the terminal. Cross-section analysis showed insufficient solder volume covering less than 75% of the joint area.
rootCause:
1. Insufficient solder paste application
2. Improper soldering iron temperature
3. Contaminated solder tip
4. Inadequate flux activation
correctiveAction:
1. Verify solder paste volume and stencil aperture size
2. Calibrate soldering iron temperature to specification (340-360Â°C)
3. Clean or replace solder tip
4. Apply additional flux before re-soldering
preventiveAction: Implement solder paste inspection (SPI) before reflow. Establish regular solder tip maintenance schedule.

name: Damage Insulation
description: Physical damage to wire insulation exposing conductor, creating potential for short circuit or electrical hazard.
failureAnalysis: Inspection found cuts, nicks, or abrasions on the insulation material. Damage depth exceeded acceptable limits per specification.
rootCause:
1. Sharp edges on tooling or fixtures
2. Excessive force during wire handling
3. Improper stripping tool settings
4. Wire routing over sharp corners
correctiveAction:
1. Replace damaged wire segment
2. Apply protective sleeving if repair is acceptable
3. Inspect adjacent wires for similar damage
preventiveAction: Install edge guards on fixtures. Implement proper wire handling training. Add inspection point after stripping operation.
applicableProcesses: OP15 - Up Side Cable Soldering Robot

name: Damage Sleeve
description: Protective sleeve shows cuts, tears, or deformation affecting its protective function and product appearance.
failureAnalysis: Visual inspection identified sleeve damage including cuts, compression marks, or heat damage. Damage compromises sleeve integrity.
rootCause:
1. Rough handling during assembly
2. Contact with sharp tooling
3. Excessive heat during soldering
4. Incorrect sleeve material specification
correctiveAction:
1. Remove damaged sleeve
2. Install new sleeve ensuring proper positioning
3. Verify sleeve material compatibility with process
preventiveAction: Use heat-resistant sleeves near soldering areas. Add protective covers during handling. Train operators on proper sleeve installation.

name: Deform Ground Shell
description: Ground shell component shows deformation, dents, or bending that affects fit, function, or appearance.
failureAnalysis: Physical inspection revealed shell deformation exceeding dimensional tolerance. Deformation affects connector mating or ground contact.
rootCause:
1. Excessive crimping force
2. Improper fixture alignment
3. Dropped product during handling
4. Incorrect tool die selection
correctiveAction:
1. Replace deformed ground shell
2. Verify crimping force settings
3. Check fixture alignment and adjust if necessary
preventiveAction: Implement force monitoring on crimping equipment. Add go/no-go gauge check after assembly. Use padded handling trays.

name: Solder Horn
description: Excess solder forming a pointed protrusion (horn or spike) on the solder joint that may cause short circuits or interference.
failureAnalysis: Visual inspection identified solder protrusion extending beyond acceptable joint profile. Horn formation poses risk of contact with adjacent components.
rootCause:
1. Improper solder iron withdrawal technique
2. Incorrect soldering temperature
3. Insufficient flux
4. Contaminated solder
correctiveAction:
1. Reheat joint and remove excess solder using solder wick
2. Reform joint with proper technique
3. Inspect for solder bridges to adjacent areas
preventiveAction: Train operators on proper iron withdrawal technique. Establish flux application standards. Implement periodic solder quality checks.

name: Stain on Insulator
description: Visible contamination, discoloration, or residue on insulator surface affecting product appearance.
failureAnalysis: Visual inspection identified foreign material or discoloration on insulator. Stain does not affect electrical function but fails cosmetic requirements.
rootCause:
1. Flux residue not properly cleaned
2. Handling with contaminated gloves
3. Oil or lubricant transfer from equipment
4. Improper storage conditions
correctiveAction:
1. Clean affected area with approved solvent
2. Re-inspect after cleaning
3. Replace if stain cannot be removed
preventiveAction: Implement cleaning process after soldering. Use lint-free gloves. Establish workstation cleanliness standards.

name: Uncut Braided Wire
description: Braided shield wire not properly cut or trimmed, leaving excess strands that may cause shorts or interference.
failureAnalysis: Inspection found untrimmed braid strands extending beyond specified length. Loose strands pose risk of electrical short or mechanical interference.
rootCause:
1. Dull cutting blade
2. Incorrect cutting parameters
3. Operator missed cutting step
4. Braid material harder than specification
correctiveAction:
1. Trim excess braid to specification
2. Verify no loose strands remain
3. Inspect braid folding and coverage
preventiveAction: Implement blade replacement schedule. Add visual aid at workstation. Include braid check in quality gate inspection.

name: Damaged Retainer
description: Retainer component shows cracks, chips, or deformation affecting its locking function.
failureAnalysis: Physical inspection revealed damage to retainer locking features. Damage may result in incomplete locking or component release.
rootCause:
1. Excessive insertion force
2. Misalignment during assembly
3. Defective incoming material
4. Dropped or mishandled component
correctiveAction:
1. Replace damaged retainer
2. Verify proper insertion technique
3. Check mating component for damage
preventiveAction: Add incoming inspection for retainer quality. Implement assembly force monitoring. Use proper handling fixtures.

name: Wrong Content of Label
description: Label contains incorrect information including wrong part number, lot number, date code, or other critical data.
failureAnalysis: Label content verification found mismatch between printed information and product specification or work order.
rootCause:
1. Incorrect label file selected
2. Data entry error in system
3. Label printer malfunction
4. Wrong label roll loaded
correctiveAction:
1. Remove incorrect label
2. Generate and apply correct label
3. Verify label content matches work order
4. Quarantine any products with wrong labels
preventiveAction: Implement barcode verification system. Add label content check to quality gate. Use label file version control.

name: Deform Clip
description: Mounting clip shows bending, warping, or deformation affecting fit or retention force.
failureAnalysis: Visual and dimensional inspection found clip deformation outside tolerance. Deformation may affect mounting security or appearance.
rootCause:
1. Improper handling during assembly
2. Excessive force during installation
3. Material defect
4. Tool damage
correctiveAction:
1. Replace deformed clip
2. Verify clip orientation and installation method
3. Check tool condition
preventiveAction: Add clip inspection before installation. Train operators on proper clip handling. Implement incoming material inspection.

name: Foreign Substance
description: Presence of foreign material, particles, or contamination on product that should not be present.
failureAnalysis: Visual inspection identified foreign particles including dust, metal shavings, or other contaminants. Contamination fails cleanliness specification.
rootCause:
1. Inadequate workstation cleanliness
2. Contamination from tooling or fixtures
3. Environmental contamination
4. Improper packaging or storage
correctiveAction:
1. Remove foreign substance using approved cleaning method
2. Re-inspect affected area
3. Check for contamination source
preventiveAction: Implement 5S workplace organization. Use air filtration in work area. Establish cleaning schedule for fixtures and tools.

name: Damaged Cable
description: Cable shows physical damage including cuts, kinks, crushing, or abrasion affecting structural integrity.
failureAnalysis: Visual and physical inspection found cable damage that compromises electrical performance or mechanical durability.
rootCause:
1. Rough handling during processing
2. Cable caught in equipment
3. Sharp edges on fixtures
4. Improper storage causing kinks
correctiveAction:
1. Isolate and scrap damaged product
2. Investigate damage source
3. Inspect adjacent products for similar damage
preventiveAction: Install cable guides and edge protectors. Train operators on proper cable handling. Use appropriate cable bend radius.

name: Protruded Insulator
description: Insulator extends beyond specified position, potentially interfering with mating or assembly.
failureAnalysis: Dimensional inspection found insulator position exceeds tolerance. Protrusion may prevent proper connector mating.
rootCause:
1. Incorrect terminal insertion depth
2. Insulator not fully seated
3. Wrong insulator part used
4. Terminal damage causing misalignment
correctiveAction:
1. Adjust insulator position to specification
2. Verify terminal insertion depth
3. Check for terminal damage
preventiveAction: Add go/no-go gauge check after insertion. Implement visual inspection aid. Verify part numbers before assembly.

name: Insufficient Insertion of Sleeve
description: Protective sleeve not fully inserted to specified position, leaving exposed area or inadequate coverage.
failureAnalysis: Visual inspection found sleeve position short of specification mark. Insufficient coverage exposes cable to potential damage.
rootCause:
1. Operator did not push sleeve fully
2. Interference from other components
3. Wrong sleeve size
4. Sleeve material friction too high
correctiveAction:
1. Reposition sleeve to correct location
2. Verify sleeve size matches specification
3. Check for interference with other components
preventiveAction: Add position marking on cable for reference. Implement sleeve insertion tool. Include position check in inspection.
applicableProcesses: OP15 - Cable Jacket Removal and Sleeve Location

name: No Dowel Mark
description: Required dowel impression mark missing from crimped connection, indicating potential crimp quality issue.
failureAnalysis: Visual inspection found absence of dowel mark on sleeve crimp. Missing mark suggests incomplete crimp cycle or tooling issue.
rootCause:
1. Worn crimping die
2. Insufficient crimp force
3. Wrong die selected
4. Part not properly positioned in die
correctiveAction:
1. Re-crimp with verified tooling
2. Inspect die condition
3. Verify crimp force meets specification
preventiveAction: Implement crimp force monitoring. Establish die replacement schedule. Add crimp mark inspection to quality gate.
